thread.title: UK weather: Icy blast sweeping in from the east to bring snow showers this week
thread.title_full: UK weather: Icy blast sweeping in from the east to bring snow showers this week

author: Danny Boyle
title: UK weather: Icy blast sweeping in from the east to bring snow showers this week
text:
News UK weather: Icy blast sweeping in from the east to bring snow showers this week A cold start to the day in the Derbyshire Peak district, as the Met Office said temperatures will likely dip by at least two or three degrees by Thursday Credit: SWNS Danny Boyle 7 February 2017 • 9:22am 
P lummeting temperatures are likely to bring flurries of snow this week as an icy blast sweeps in from the east. 
Forecasters have warned that colder temperatures will spread across Britain from Wednesday, accompanied by the chance of wintry showers. 
The Met Office said clear skies will likely see temperatures dip by at least two or three degrees by Thursday for much of England, with daytime maximums not expected to rise higher than around 5C (41F). Our weather pattern changes from its prevailing south-westerly influence to more of an easterly one this week - turning much colder pic.twitter.com/wE7kQlzibv — Met Office (@metoffice) February 6, 2017 
"We'll definitely be seeing low single figures by the end of the week," said Met Office forecaster Emma Sharples. 
"And, of course, overnight, where skies remain clear and away from coastal areas, we'll see temperatures dipping down to negative figures 
"The wind will start to pick up from the east, so it's not just numerically temperatures being low but, also, the wind chill's going to add to that as well." You may have heard it's set to turn colder this week as high pressure builds and winds blow from the east. Here's the latest: pic.twitter.com/CfErznfbfk — Met Office (@metoffice) February 6, 2017 
S he said the colder temperatures could be accompanied by the odd wintry flurry, mostly in the east. 
The Met Office is not currently expecting these to be significant snow falls. 
"There will be some snow around," Ms Sharples said. "It looks like there will be some wintry flurries down the east coast on Thursday, Friday and into Saturday. 
"It's difficult at the moment to say exactly where we'll see those, but it's definitely turning cold enough."
